title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. You will then have to wait three months after the samples come back clear to get the health certicate.The best thing to do is contact your vet for the latest advice four months before you hope to travel. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carlukegazette webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CE marking after Brexit"  CE marking after Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "CARL | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "CARL | Article Teaser"

title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . The other schools at the event were Aberdeen Grammar, the International School Aberdeen, Oldmachar Academy, Albyn School, Mintlaw Academy, Robert Gordon’s College and Peterhead Academy.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jemima Adeoye, Director of Education and Childrens Services Laurence Findlay, Elizabeth Lyall, Cooper Masson, Cllr Gillian Owen, Cllr Jim Gford, Provost Bill Howatson, Chief Executive Jim Savege, Tami Fadeyi, Ruaridh Cumming and Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar with pupils outside the new Kinellar School"  Community celebrates official opening of Kinellar School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: uryside park secures european funding
story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Dingwall sale brings lots of joy to charities
story: CHARITIES which help Highland cancer patients in their time of need will share a pound, windfall from a special auction in Dingwall.The event at Dingwall Auction Mart had originally been put together to raise funds for Beauly mother-of-two Roz Paterson who had been aiming to secure pound, to fund potentially le-saving treatment in the United States,Her condition has proved resistant to several forms of chemotherapy leaving her facing a race against the clock to try and access expensive Car-T cell therapy in Boston.When it emerged that her treatment will now be funded on the NHS much closer to home, a decision was taken that the mart auction would go ahead ndash with four key Highland charities benefiting instead.Supporters of the Raising for Roz campaign had come up trumps with more than  lots put forward.The go-ahead for the auction provided a welcome boost for Highland Hospice, Marie Curie, MacMillan Nurses and Maggiersquos Highland.The star lot was a wedding package worth pound, which was snapped up by Inverness couple Alison Ireland and Christian Kenway for pound.Auction organiser Willie Matheson hailed the full-house auction a great success. He said: ldquoThe star lot was the wedding package which was quite unique and went to a local girl. That meant a lot to us and a lot to me especially.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwalls Nordic past to live again through trail
story: VIKING culturersquos key role in Dingwallrsquos history could soon be highlighted by a long-awaited heritage trail around the town ndash thanks to the efforts of enterprising residents.The Dingwall Community Development Companyhas already enjoyed considerable but muted success as the recently formed group continues to build membership and go after funding.So far DCDC has funnelled pound of cash from the Gough Charitable Trust to revamping the seating and paths at popular Ferry Point on the shores of the Cromarty Firth. But after holding the first AGM last week, the group now wants to go after larger projects through the lottery funding.The ultimate ambition is to renovate Dingwall Town Hall and ensure it is brought into regular and sustained use by locals and visitors as a focal point of the town.Before that, the DCDC directors and trustees, comprising Janet Bowen, Debbie Downie, Robin Lingard and Nigel Greenwood have been ldquosting through the communityrsquos suggestions for improvements to the town.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoDingwall is very fortunate to have a number of organisations which are dedicated to making the town an attractive and welcoming place. But we want to use our charitable status to unlock funding for capital projects which should make a signicant dference in raising Dingwallrsquos profile.The first of those projects out of the traps has been developed with the help of the Dingwall History Society and is a heritage trail around the town which stops off at around a dozen sites.Among them are the memorial next to the train station, the birthplace of MacBeth ndash Dingwall Castle, as well as the Macdonald Monument and others.Mrs Bowen said: ldquoUsing a series of display  to highlight to both local people and visitors the richness of Dingwallrsquos history, especially as a Viking settlement.A sticking point however is that the bridge over the Dingwall canal is closed due to safety concerns.ldquoThe big issue here, of course, is the future of the footbridge across the Dingwall canal, which has been out of use for some time now because of safety fears. The community council is very anxious to bring it back into use and we are looking at what role we might play in helping to bring it back into use.Many local groups feel that Dingwallrsquos Viking heritage has been a little neglected but in  archaeologists and historians managed to flesh out the legends. They confirmed that the townrsquos Cromartie car park was the site of a Viking parliament or meeting place ndash called a lsquoThingwallrsquo ndash from which Dingwall get its name.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross gymnastics club storms to national success
story: GOLDEN girls from a flourishing Easter Ross gymnastics club thrilled judges to take a top title only six months after starting a new discipline.Fyrish Gymnastics Clubrsquos success at the  Scottish National TeamGym Championships held at Meadowmill Sports Centre in Tranent last weekend.came after the Alness-based Scottish Gymnastics club of the year made the eight-hour round trip to compete against well-established TeamGym clubs Irvine Bay, Forth Valley, Midlothian and Saltire.The discipline is credited with keeping gymnasts involved in the sport longer. The open level  team stole the show with their floor routine which clinched gold ndash and the Scottish national title, only six months after starting the discipline.Fyrish TeamGym head coach, Heidi Bavnhoslashj, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing, we were all crying! We started in August and now wersquove won! One of the judges came over to compliment us on our floor routine so I thought we might get a bronze ndash but never did I think we could win!ldquoThese girls, their parents and the club have provided the best support. We started off with eight gymnasts interested [in TeamGym] now we are up to . Itrsquos going to keep more gymnasts involved in the sport longer as the club have really embraced it.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Glenmorangie taps into global demand with new developments
story: AN historic Easter Ross distiller intends satisfying a global thirst for its drams with a multimillion-pound development at its Tain base.Work by Morrison Construction on a new still house and additional mashing and fermentation facilities is now under way at Glenmorangiersquos plant. The new still house will showcase two more of the firmrsquos signature copper stills, the tallest in Scotland.A separate building using reclaimed stone salvaged from distillery warehouses will provide the additional mashing and fermentation facilities. Two new warehouses are also under construction.A Glenmorangie spokesperson told the Journal: ldquoOur new still house, as well as the additional mashing and fermentation facilities, will position Glenmorangie for ever-greater success and ensure that the distillery can continue to satisfy the worldrsquos growing appetite for our award-winning single malt Scotch whisky.ldquoThis year we have added new management and engineering roles at the distillery and once operational, the expansion will create two additional roles.Its drams are perfected by the ldquoMen of Tain, who have passed their skills down the generations. title: Highland seafood firm goes into liquidation
story: A Highland seafood firm set up by an award-winning entrepreneur has gone into voluntary liquidation.Coast and Glen, founded by Magnus Houston in , had grown rapidly in recent years, supplying fresh fish and game to hotels and restaurants across the UK and had also expanded direct sales to consumers.The business, which employed nine people and had a turnover of pound. million, operated from fully-fitted leased premises in Alness and had also acquired a new  sq ft factory in Muir of Ord.Its liquidation was attributed to unsustainable cash flow problems stemming from rising costs, intense competition and very low margins.Mr Houston, a former motorcycle racer, taught himself the trade after a bad crash.His other business, Fishbox, is unaffected.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents blast council for not seeking cash to fix crumbling Dingwall school
story: SOME of the most vulnerable pupils in Ross-shire have been treated with "utter contempt" by the local authority which has misled parents and failed to seek "a single penny" of extra cash from the Scottish government.That was the damning indictment this week ahead of a crunch meeting on the future of St Clements in Dingwall before Highland Council sets its budget.Members of the parent-teacher council have already written to every single councillor urging them to take long-promised action to resolve severe problems with school building declared unfit for purpose by the governments childrens minister.The Scottish Government has confirmed the local authority has not sought funding for St. Clementrsquos from the the Scotland Schools for the Future programme.The next tranche of the pound billion announced last November will only be available from  leaving teachers and pupils enduring years more hardship in a building branded "Dickensian" by local MSP Kate Forbes.A Scottish government spokesman said: ldquoWe have been made aware that St. Clementrsquos is in poor condition, however it is the statutory responsibility of Highland Council to manage and maintain its school estate.ldquoThe Scottish government has provided signicant funding of over poundm in recent years towards five projects through its existing school building programme, Scotland Schools for the Future, all of which were Highland Councilrsquos priority projects for investment. Highland Council has not asked the Scottish Government for support in relation to St Clementrsquos.Christyna Ferguson, whose daughter suffering a series of complex health issues including autism attends the school, slammed the councilrsquos inaction "utter contempt for the already disadvantaged, vulnerable children".She said: "The Highland Council repeatedly told us that St.Clementrsquos appalling lack of facilities was due to a lack of Scottish government funding. Therefore it is misleading at best and shows not only non-compliance with their statuary obligations but utter contempt for the children."In the last year the Highland Council has taken no action to survey sites, secure funding or build a business plan despite assuring us they would."She insisted: ldquoHighland Council does have options in terms of funding solutions but they repeatedly refuse to engage in the process ndash again failing in their statutory obligations and causing unnecessary suffering and detriment to disabled children. It is incomprehensible to me that those with the power and the obligation in law can show such blatant disregard for disabled children."Dingwall-based MSP Kate Forbes said: "As the daughter of a former teacher at St Clementrsquos, I am in no doubt as to the poor condition of the buildings. It is remarkable the teachers are able to care for and teach the pupils in such a damp, cramped building.ldquoThere is a desperate need for a new building, delivered in consultation with parents and teachers. This is, of course, a matter for Highland Council who are statutorily responsible for school buildings but I think everybody wants to see a solution."I am more than happy to work with anybody and everybody to find a solution and would sincerely hope that wersquore not still talking about school buildings in another  years."Childrenrsquos minister Maree Todd, also a Ross-shire-based SNP MSP, said: "The school has not previously been prioritised by Highland Council in their capital spending plans despite being in a poor condition."Itrsquos nearly a year since I first raised concerns with the council so I look forward to meeting with councillors and officers at the end of this month to hear an update on progress. All children, especially those who are disadvantaged and vulnerable, deserve our help to enable them to, not only fulfil, but to exceed their potential. That is why it is vital that we can find the right solution for the pupils, parents and the wider St Clementrsquos community.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: "At this point in time we are addressing our capital plan for next year and the process is still ongoing. The council has been in dialogue with Scottish Government and highlighted the  school locations, including St Clements, which were identied by the council in March  as priorities for bids to Scottish Government. We are not aware of any Scottish Government Funding prior to ."Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: People power sees safety measures considered for Tain junctions at last
story: HOPES are high that action will finally now be taken at two of the most dangerous road junctions in Easter Ross following a string of accidents and near-misses.Concerns about Tainrsquos two main junctions with the A prompted campaigners to claim a failure by roads chiefs to act would ldquoinevitably lead to someone being killed.Tain and Easter Ross councillor Derek Louden was joined by politicians from across the political spectrum in flagging up concerns, among them local MP Jamie Stone who said he had ldquopersonally witnessed more smashes than I care to remember and that ldquothere is something terribly wrong here.Campaigners had suggested a iety of possible measures, including reducing the speed limit, changing the road layout and even the installation of roundabouts ndash but their pleas fell on deaf ears.However, Transport Scotlandrsquos new area road safety manager, Richard Perry, has told Cllr Louden draft proposals have now been drawn up following an analysis of collisions at the north and south junctions by trunk road operator BEAR Scotland.Short-term measures could include enhanced signage, improved surfacing and better road markings.In the medium term, improvements to the bell mouth radius of the south junction will be considered.The possibility of reducing the speed limit on the bypass section to mph will also be investigated, but this would require statutory processes and consultation.Mr Perry said the construction of a roundabout could be considered, but would require agreement on funding.Cllr Louden told the Journal he was delighted to hear safety could finally be improved at the dangerous junctions.He welcomed the widening of the exits to allow lorries and buses to get onto the A without having to use the central reservation.And he said he was pleased to see a commitment to holding a consultation on reducing the speed limit on the bypass ldquoso that when accidents do occur, they are less likely to be fatal.He said he hoped efforts would begin early this year, as suggested in the letter.An initial review by roads chiefs noted a disproportionate number of incidents with buses and heavy goods vehicles exiting the minor road to enter the A into the path of approaching vehicles and ldquoa small number of poorly judged overtaking manoeuvres through the A junction.Tain Community Council previously said that simply blaming driver error was ldquoa cop out which failed to tackle the issue of two dangerous junctions.It warned the roadrsquos inclusion on the NC made accidents more likely.What do you think  Email us title: Stone
story: Highlighting the "great historic good" the European Structural Fund has brought to Ross-shire, Easter Ross MP Jamie Stone said: "It paid for new airports, roads, economic development and tourism.ldquoWhen I asked the Prime Minister what would replace this she referred me to the Shared Prosperity Fund. We are very scant on the details of a Shared Prosperity Fund."Could I respectfully ask the Prime Minister to ask officials to meet with myself and other interested members of parliament to discuss what this fund might be and how it might apply to areas of the UK such as my constituency.Mrs May said she is currently in the process of consulting on the nature of the Shared Prosperity Fund and the criteria within which it will work "so I will ask relevant officials to meet with the honourable gentleman in the way he has requested",Mr Stone though said afterwards: "It is clear that there is nothing concrete about a Shared Prosperity Fund. This was the third time I have asked for details on the proposed replacement funding and for the third time I have not received an answer."The Highlands cannot rely on hypothetical funding and Theresa Mayrsquos lack of clarity shows she is aware leaving the EU will make my constituency worse off.ldquoThis comes as it is estimated that the Highlands and Islands would have been entitled to approximately pound million in EU funding between -.ldquoLeaving the EU, particularly crashing out as Theresa May seems to be advocating, would be a disaster for my constituency."I am elected to represent my constituentsrsquo interests and given the shortfall in funding that the Highlands would face in the case of Brexit, I cannot support anything that will make them worse off.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-group, leave a comment or write to us at the address on our letters page.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Strathpeffer author pays tribute to charity that was there to help
story: A STRONG-WILLED Strath-peffer author who lost her sight aged  has paid tribute to the Highland charity that got her through the hardest days of her le.Emily Gray descended into misery after the  diagnosis, but said Sight Action showed her how to be happy again.The -year-old, whose childrenrsquos book Priscilla the Pig has just hit the shelves, said the support from the Inverness-based team was transformational.ldquoThey were brilliant, they changed my le, she said. ldquoIrsquove gained confidence to do everything.Miss Gray lost her sight when she was just  due to problems brought on by Type  diabetes.Looking back on the experience, which forced her to drop her music degree at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, Miss Gray, who now has a guide dog called April, said: ldquoI was in limbo. I didnrsquot do anything. I couldnrsquot go out by myself. It was not a nice place to be in...I was just existing and no more. All the hopes I had for the future were gone. I just felt like I had lost everything.The mum-of-one was referred by a specialist to Sight Action and the charityrsquos rehabilitation worker Brenda Smart became her strongest ally.The -year-old who is also the organisationrsquos client service manager was bowled over by Miss Grayrsquos resolve.ldquoWhen I first met her, I thought lsquothis is quite a determined young ladyrsquo. There were times when she doubted herself, but she put everything into it.Mrs Smart said cooking skills were important for Miss Gray.ldquoI showed her how to weigh out the recipes and all the things thatyoursquore sighted you do without thinking about it. Even the tidying up a bit, sweeping the floor, vacuuming. I showed her how to do that with a grid so she can tellshersquos got most of it up.ldquoAnd when she was pregnant we took out a baby doll and practised putting the baby in the carrier and changing the nappies on the doll. And when Harris was born she was absolutely brilliant. Irsquom really proud of her.Book publisher James Houghton of Olympia Publishing said: ldquoWhen considering the work, I was not aware Emily was blind. She is a great example of not letting a disability stand in your way.During pregnancy, Emily, who writes under the pen name Madeline Rose, mused over her own childhood and settled into writing her first story inspired by her mumrsquo Heatherrsquos tales of le on a farm in Dingwall using a voiceover computer programme.It is illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist, Sarah Jane Cumberford.Thursday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: bumper membership at scottish motor trade association
story: Scotland#s motor trade body has seen membership accelerate through the , mark # the highest level in more than  years.Sandy Burgess, chief executive of the Scottish Motor Trade Association , said he was “delighted” at the growth in numbers, coming as it does during a turbulent period for the industry.“It is fantastic to see our membership continue to grow, signicantly in the SME [small and medium-sized enterprise] and independent sector, and it is encouraging to see that in these challenging times that the motor industry is facing we are able to expand our membership base across Scotland and many of the islands.“SMTA has much to offer the Scottish motor trade including our unique buying group, our modern apprenticeship scheme soon to be supported by an exciting online training programme, our in-house MOT product, as well as our fully Scottish-based used car warranty company Scotsure and access to our industry specic SMTA digital marketing service.”The association, which was founded in , has its headquarters in South Queensferry.Last week, it emerged that new car sales had motored ahead last month in Scotland, bucking the downward trend seen where in the UK.There was a . per cent hike in new car registrations in Scotland during January, compared with the same month last year. Almost , vehicles were bought, up from , a year earlier.Sales of new cars for the UK as a whole fell last month although demand for electric models surged.Burgess said at the time: “Whilst there is no doubt that some of the growth will be as a result of units from previous delayed deliveries coming through, we are still signicantly better than the tracking performance where in the UK.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: church of scotland minister clashes with american cruise operator over r kelly
story: Members of a Church of Scotland congregation clashed with security on a cruise ship after a DJ refused to stop playing songs by American pop star R Kelly.The Rev. Teri Peterson and several members of her congregation from Gourock, Inverclyde, were on holiday in Miami when the incident took place.The women had joined other members of the RevGalBlogPals- an international online community which supports clergywomen and other women in ministry.But while aboard the Carnival Magic liner, the friends were outraged by a DJ playing R Kelly songs at the ship’s nightclub.Mrs Peterson is an office bearer with RevGalBlogPals and has now filed a complaint against the cruise liner operators on their behalf.They claim the trip was ruined by a DJ who “mocked” their request to stop playing tunes by the RB star.American singer R Kelly has been the subject of multiple allegations of sexual abuse against women and underage girls for many years, with some cases settled out of court and the singer acquitted of some charges.But last month, prosecutors in Atlanta and Chicago began new investigations into allegations of abuse.The Rev Peterson, who came to Scotland from Chicago, said: “The DJ started to play R Kelly and was asked by our group to put it off because of everything surrounding the singer “He refused and then began singing and dancing along and mocking us.”The minister claimed the women left the club, only to be made fun of again by the same man later that night in another part of the ship.Rev Paterson says she spent five days emailing the company, speaking with ship staff and sitting in meetings with onboard management.But they never received a resolution to their complaint and were unhappy with the  onboard credit offered as compensation.In a letter to the group, the company vehemently defended their actions and stated that the  settlement was ‘appropriate’.The letter read: “We have clear guidelines for music that is played in our public lounges.“Some latitude is extended to the DJs in our nightclubs in order to accommodate the preferences of all of our guests.“All music that is played is “radio version” recordings of popular music that is edited for offensive language.“With regard the incident on Carnival Magic, we counselled the DJ and the entertainment team to be respectful of your concerns as you clearly felt that they were not.”Rev Peterson said: “The response from Carnival makes me really angry.“They had so many chances to do better and do the right thing, but they made it worse.”She added: “We want Carnival to first of all apologise for a signicant customer service failure and to make sure that there are better choices in their music and entertainment line up.“Also to update their training so that this doesn’t happen to anyone .”A spokesman for Carnival Cruise Line said: “We had a small group of guests who took issue with two songs that our DJ was playing in a nightclub well after midnight.“While we only play radio versions of popular music that have been sanitised so that offensive language has been removed, we do not make a habit of banning music as we have a broad cross section of guests.“Our shipboard team listened to the concerns of these guests and provided a goodwill gesture.“We are proud of the many ways we’ve been recognised for our commitment to ersity and inclusion and every day we work to make sure our guests and crew feel welcome and part of the Carnival family.“We’re sorry this group feels otherwise.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: meet the scottish great grandad who s the uk s longest serving football manager
story: Meet Britain#s longest serving football manager # an octogenarian who has been in the job for  years.Larry Barilli, , has been a player and manager since he was . He played in  cup finals, winning  of them, and has  league titles under his belt.The amateur footballing stalwart, who lives in Greenock in Inverclyde, first set up a team aged  and kept on playing into his s in his role as an inside left.His career as a manager has exceeded even his hero Alex Ferguson’s for longevity by  years. Despite his age, the great-grandfather can still do keepie-uppies.His first team, Barnhill Rovers, was named after the street where he grew up.The latest, formerly named Bayhome Builders FC, was renamed Chaplins FC two years ago.Larry, who has only missed six games in  years, lamented “too much pushing, shoving and pulling shirts” in the beautul game.He has stern words for modern footballers, saying: “There is too much passing about at the back now for my liking.“When I played you were always trying to get forward to score a goal.“Now they will pass all day, they are all at it.“There is also a lot more pushing, shoving and pulling shirts.“When I played I was never ever booked.”Every Sunday he sends his players onto the pitch, in all weathers, and watches from the touchline.And despite his age, the father-of-six, who still works part time as a taxi driver, takes home the players’ laundry every week.He no longer attends mid-week practices, but says after the death of his we, the footballers have become his second family.When he is not cheering on his own team, which play in the Greenock District Welfare League, Larry takes a keen interest in Greenock Morton FC.And he keeps an eye on Celtic in the Premiership, but said sometimes their playing is ‘boring’, with too much passing.Great-grandfather-of-nine Larry said: “I was over  when I stopped playing.“When you are getting a lot of players coming through, it is hard to pick yourself to play.“It is not nice to pick yourself in front of others.”He added: “My career has been longer than Fergie’s. In  years I’ve missed maybe half a dozen games.“But there’s an awful lot of pushing and shoving and I don’t think it’s a good thing.”Larry also disagreed with post-match referrals to a committee to make a decision about a players’ behaviour.“It’s something for the ref,” he said.“Celtic are very good at passing it back. It certainly is very boring.“I think Scotland will qualy for the next World Cup. I feel sorry for the managers – the clubs should come before the national team.“I think Scotland could do quite well. The managers are trying very hard.“They have not had very much luck.“I think most teams have got one of those players that will be a bit rough and get booked.“I loved it when I was playing football.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: ian blackford repeats claim that theresa may lied about brexit deal analysis
story: The SNP#s Westminster leader has repeated his claim that Theresa May lied about analysis of her Brexit deal and suggested she is not #fit for the office of Prime Minister#.Ian Blackford was forced to withdraw remarks in the Commons chamber on Tuesday after shouting at the Prime Minister that she was a “liar”.But speaking to journalists following Prime Minister’s Questions, he stood by his comment, saying the government’s own economic analysis of Brexit options made clear that the ‘bespoke’ trade deal sought with the EU could not be modelled yet.“I think she’s got to take a bit more care as to the statements that she uses in the House of Commons,” Mr Blackford said. “It’s unbecoming of a Prime Minister to behave in such a manner. “In fact, I’ll go further than that.“ I don’t think a Prime Minister that behaves in such a way has the characteristics of a person that is fit for the office of Prime Minister.”With the UK government repeating that it is ready to leave the EU without a deal, Mr Blackford added: “I would seriously question [the Prime Minister’s] sanityshe thinks that we should be contemplating a no-deal.”At PMQs, Mrs May sparked fresh anger on the SNP benches by claiming Scottish independence would have meant a ‘no-deal exit’ from the EU.“He complains about no deal, but of course, it was the Scottish National party who wanted to leave the UK without a plan,” the Prime Minister told Mr Blackford. “Perhaps we should remind the SNP that independence would have meant leaving the EU with no deal.”The SNP had an aide bring a copy of the white paper on independence to the Commons chamber, where it was held up by Mr Blackford in a point of order at the end of PMQs.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: theresa may faces another embarrassing commons defeat on brexit
story: Theresa May is facing another embarrassing defeat after Tory eurosceptics warned they would vote against a symbolic motion on Brexit this evening unless it keeps the option of no deal on the table.Downing Street denied the Prime Minister was ruling out a no-deal scenario by ­asking MPs to reaffirm the position following the last series of votes in January, which saw an amendment passed calling for no deal to be taken off the table.But members of the European Research Groupsaid they would not back today’s motion unless the wording was changed, risking embarrassment for the government and undermining attempts to secure concessions from Brussels on the Brexit deal.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the Prime Minister must immediately remove the threat of a no-deal Brexit, warning it “increasingly appears to be the most likely outcome”. The latest conflict within the Conservative Party follows reports that the Prime Minister’s chief adviser on Europe, civil servant Olly Robbins, was overheard in a Brussels bar saying MPs would eventually be given the choice between accepting Mrs May’s deal or a signicant delay to Brexit.Mr Robbins, who has become a target for attacks by Tory MPs, was also reported to have said the controversial “backstop” provision to prevent a hard border in Ireland would become a “bridge” to the future relationship with the EU, signalling close adherence to Brussels rules.At Prime Minister’s Questions yesterday, SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford told Mrs May she had been “rumbled by your own loose-lipped senior Brexit adviser”.There were howls of anger from Eurosceptics over Mr Robbins’s reported comments, with former Ukip leader Nigel Farage calling for him to be sacked for “treachery and incompetence”. But Mrs May dismissed the issue as “what someone said to someone , as overheard by someone , in a bar”.And Conservative vice-chairman Chris Philp said: “What a civil servant might speculate in a bar after a few drinks is frankly not that important.”Downing Street denied the backstop would serve as a bridge, insisting it was “an insurance policy that is never intended to be used”.Speaking to the BBC ahead of today’s vote on the government’s “neutral” motion, ERG vice-chairman Mark Francois said: “We cannot vote for this as it is currently configured because it rules out no deal and removes our negotiating leverage in Brussels.“The Prime Minister,she went through the lobbies for this tomorrow night, would be voting against the guarantees she has given in the Commons for months. It is madness.”Mrs May’s official spokesman said: “What the motion reflects is the position the Prime Minister set out after those votes, which is the Parliament wants the UK to leave with a deal, but in order to do so it requires us to secure legally-binding changes in relation to the backstop.”He added: “No deal is an eventuality we wish to avoid, but one we continue to plan for. Does no deal remain on the table  The answer is yes.”Labour has tabled an amendment for debate in the Commons today that would require the Prime Minister to either put her deal to a vote by  February or allow Parliament to take control of the process.Veteran Tory Europhile Kenneth Clarke has tabled a further amendment, backed by senior figures from across the House, including Labour’s Harriet Harman, which would allow MPs to vote for their preferred Brexit outcome. His plan envisages MPs ranking options in order of preference on a ballot paper.An amendment from Labour MP Roger Godsf calls for an extension of the two-year Brexit negotiation period to allow for a second referendum.Another tabled by the SNP’s Angus MacNeil calls on Mrs May simply to revoke the Article  letter informing the EU of Britain’s intention to leave.Meanwhile, a cross-party initiative backed by Tory Anna Soubry and Labour’s Chuka Umunna demands the government publish its most recent official briefing on the implications of a no-deal Brexit for business and trade.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: first look at the jarls squad
story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. title: halcro johnston welcomes comments from senior snp minister on ferry funding
story: Signs have emerged of a softening in the Scottish government#s approach to fair ferry funding, with one Tory MSP insisting a senior SNP colleague has given backing for a better deal on leline links.Isles councillors have been left frustrated by the Scottish government#s funding offer following its budget, not least because of a shortfall in ferry funding.Complaints have been made by island leaders that the funding settlement, agreed last year, does not meet the full costs of running the internal ferries in Orkney and in Shetland.In the Western Isles the costs are met by the Scottish government as part of Clyde and Hebridean ferry service contract.But Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston had highlighted a visit to Orkney by the SNP #s constitutional relations secretary, Mike Russell.Jamie Halcro JohnstonAccording to a news release dispatched on Thursday, Mr Russell told The Orcadian newspaper: “I can take that back, and I can say to my colleagues, look this is a big issue in Orkney, and obviously it needs a resolution”.Mr Halcro Johnston welcomed the cabinet secretary’s acknowledgement that a resolution was required and urged one to be brought forward.“I welcome news of Mike Russell’s comments on fair ferry funding, and I’m encouraged by the intervention of a senior SNP minister. As a representative for Argyll and Bute, Mr Russell clearly understands ferry issues rather better than some of his government colleagues.#It comes after the Scottish government agreed to alter its spending plans with support from the Scottish Greens.The Greens said the Scottish government had agreed to alter its spending plans in exchange for support in getting the budget through.SIC leader Steven Coutts told The Shetland Times on Thursday: #At the moment we#re still waiting to see the final full detail on the back of the deal that was done between the Green Party and the SNP. We need to see what the figures actually mean.#There#s still no commitment on full and fair ferry funding, and that#s something we#ll want to press the government and Green Party on.#..

title: council adjourns decision on viking energy
story: A meeting to determine whether the council will object to an application to increase the size of the turbines which would form the Viking Energy windfarm has been adjourned amid confusion among members.The firm is seeking permission to increase the height of the proposed  turbines by  metres to a maximum of  metres.The Scottish government will have the final say on whether the project goes ahead but councillors met on Wednesday afternoon to discuss whether the local authority would, as a formal consultee, object to the application.Councillors expressed dismay saying that it was unclear which new or modied conditions were being considered. Those matters already determined in  and  were not under the microscope.Lerwick South councillor Cecil Smith said that he also felt uncomfortable that this decision was being taken by the council#s planning committee, with just a handful of members present, as opposed to the full council.However, he was informed that a decision had to be made within  hoursthe council were to fulfil its duty as a statutory consultee.Meanwhile, Shetland South member George Smith said that he wanted a new report brought before the council which made it clear what specic issues were relevant to the ied consent application.Councillor Catherine Hughson asked whether an extension could be granted to allow the council further time to consider its response.The meeting was adjourned to allow the council#s corporate services executive manager Jan Riise to seek clarity on this issue.. raquo..
